39.text: [39] The appearances of this mysterious chord divide the piece into three sections: mm. 1–10, mm. 11–28, and mm. 29–35. Each of the sections makes a distinct attempt to tease out some of the potentials of the opening chord. The first section is shown as Example 35a . Measure 3 replaces the E and D of the whole-tone chord with E ♭ and puts B ♭ lower down in the voicing, transforming the mysterious chord into a straightforward C half-diminished seventh chord; E ♭ is asserted as more structural than D in the upper voice, which reprises the descent from E ♭ 5 to B ♭ 4. The C half-diminished seventh chord then takes on two tonal roles: it serves first as ii ø7 in B ♭ in mm. 3–4, and then, after the revoicing described in the discussion of Example 11, retrospectively as a chromatic iiiø 7 in the root progression C– E ♭ – A ♭ . The A ♭ minor arrived at in m. 6 is extended with chromatic embellishment in mm. 7–8, but then dissipates amidst more chromatic activity in mm. 9–10.

40.text: [40] The second section ( Example 35b ), which begins with a verbatim restatement of the opening bar, explores other tonal contexts for the C-rooted tonal plausibility of the mysterious chord. In m. 12 the chord is again transformed into a C half-diminished seventh chord, and m. 12 reprises the C– E ♭ root motion of m. 5. The melody, however, ascends rather than descends chromatically from E ♭ and, as if discarding the C half-diminished seventh chord’s previous role as chromatic iiiø 7 , the music in m. 13 recasts the same half-diminished seventh chord as vii ø7 in D ♭ minor, cadencing in m. 14 with the progression vii ø7 –V 7 –i.

41.text: [41] This way of utilizing a C-rooted chord is left behind in m. 15, which undermines the key of D ♭ minor by replacing the expected conclusion of the extended bass appoggiatura on D ♭ 4 with a C4 instead. (The E ♭ 4 on the downbeat of m. 15 is heard as an appoggiatura in part because the ro- interval 1 it forms with F ♭ 4 suggests that the initial verticality is a chord with nonessential dissonance rather than an integrated chord). The subsequent music then further transforms the mysterious chord into a C-rooted dominant-seventh chord in F minor; in mm. 16–17 B-natural is a chromatic passing tone on the way to B ♭ in the V 7 chord, with its status as a nonharmonic tone again emphasized by the voicings with ro -interval 1 (B3–C4) on each downbeat. This tonal context for a C-rooted chord is undermined in mm. 18–19, when G in the bass resolves to F ♯ rather than F and thus thwarts the appearance of the implied F-minor tonic triad. The next gambit, in this ongoing quest to find a suitable home for the C-rooted tonal plausibility latent in the mysterious chord, is to cast C as tonic; the harmonies in mm. 20–21 are based on C and in mm. 22–23 on its |10|-anchored dominant. The increasing intensity of the search can perhaps be heard in the non-resolution of the ro -interval 1s in mm. 20–21: these are the only instances of ro -interval 1 in the piece that do not either conform to the anchor-structure model’s voicing restrictions or resolve simply as nonharmonic tones. The key of C major soon evaporates as well; the chromatic descent in the inner voice from F3 in m. 22 to D ♭ 3 in m. 25 gradually turns G7 into E ♭ 7 and then B ♭ minor. Frustrated, the piece climbs to its only loud dynamic, forte in m. 27, and becomes entirely octatonic for six beats as if to give up in its search for a key. The piano subito in m. 28 arrives with the pitches of the opening arpeggio, minus D, revoiced in the upper register. (50) F ♯ then resolves to G, producing a C dominant-seventh chord in third inversion. This bar’s transformation of a whole-tone chord into an anxious, forward-looking dominant-seventh chord emblematizes this section’s failed questing after tonal resolution and harkens back to the thwarted cadential approach to F minor earlier in this section.

42.text: [42] The third portion of the piece ( Example 35c ) embraces the ambiguity of the mysterious chord rather than attempting to tame it via transformation. The appearances of the chord in mm. 29–30 are altered to emphasize the chord’s whole-tone makeup: A ♭ 4 is inserted into the chord, completing the WT 0 collection, and the upper-voice downbeat E ♭ is replaced with an E-natural. The metric readjustment of the progression from mm. 5–6 in m. 31 serves to establish the whole-tone version of the mysterious chord as contextually stable; the root of B ♭ is no longer a harmonic goal on the downbeat of a 3/4 bar, but rather a weak-beat step on the way back to C. The version of the mysterious chord in m. 32 is also completely whole-tone, and has D-natural5 as the upper pitch. This is followed by a single-line chromatic descent from G ♭ 4 to B ♭ 3 (replicated two octaves above) that begins with the pickup to m. 33 and ends in m. 36 on the C half-diminished seventh chord that is the final chord of the piece. The right hand plays the perfect fifth E ♭ 5– B ♭ 5; highlighting as it does the most stable constituent interval of the half-diminished seventh chord, this ending perhaps suggests that this is a suitable resolution for the C-rooted potential in the mysterious opening chord, and that all the previous attempts to install it in one key or another were unnecessary.

43.text: [43] Voicing and additive harmony are topics on the margins of theories of harmony; conventional models of harmony privilege chord inversion, reduction, and deeper levels of tonal structure over surface details. This essay, though, has hopefully demonstrated not only how powerful a voicing-based model for additive harmony can be but also how the seemingly small, surface-detail topics of voicing and additive harmony relate to larger music-theoretical issues. For one, the anchor-structure model touches on how musical practices can relate to and be informed by our psychoacoustic apparatus. The strain of experimental research referenced in this article suggests that listeners are highly sensitive to voicing and other surface details. Many of the mechanisms of conventional theory, though, rely on concepts (such as interval class) that operate at a level of remove from the musical surface. The anchor-structure model bypasses much of that abstraction, and makes use of our fundamental cognitive processes—e.g. our ability to recognize acoustically salient intervals, or our sensitivity to the roughness of ro -interval 1—to describe how listeners interact with additive-harmonic surfaces. A good portion of the resultant pragmatic, figured-bass approach may be based on common sense, but it is common sense that is often either left unsaid or obscured by underdeveloped, back-of-the-book models of additive harmony. The anchor-structure model also engages with the methodological premise that one of the aims of music theory is to describe how musical structures relate to shared cultural assumptions between audiences and producers ( Gjerdingen 2007 , 16–19). Chord structure in the anchor-structure model is conceived of as a set of stylistic constraints that allowed novel chords to assimilate into the common-practice structures with which Parisian audiences of the time would have been familiar. To close, I will suggest that the anchor-structure model adds a new dimension to our understanding of the development of tonal language in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The most common narrative of that era is of how adherence to certain common-practice voice-leading principles allowed for the incorporation of new harmonic successions into tonal contexts. The anchor-structure model enables the development of additive harmony to be read in parallel fashion: it is adherence to certain vertical-domain common-practice principles—skeletal voicings derived from common-practice chords and generalized principles of pitch combination—that made the incorporation of new chords into tonal contexts possible.
